algorithms.title: Algorithm Families Overview
algorithms.description: Common remote sensing and image processing algorithm categories used in satellite data analysis

families.name: Super-Resolution (SR)
families.description: Techniques for enhancing spatial resolution of imagery through reconstruction algorithms. Methods include interpolation-based, learning-based, and multi-frame approaches. Performance depends on input quality and scene complexity.

families.name: Segmentation
families.description: Algorithms for partitioning images into meaningful regions or objects. Includes threshold-based, region-growing, edge-based, and ML-based methods. Accuracy varies with scene heterogeneity and parameter tuning.

families.name: Change Detection
families.description: Methods for identifying temporal differences between multi-date imagery. Common approaches include image differencing, ratio methods, and classification comparison. Results depend on co-registration accuracy and radiometric consistency.

families.name: Pansharpening
families.description: Fusion of high-resolution panchromatic and lower-resolution multispectral imagery. Techniques include component substitution, multi-resolution analysis, and model-based methods. Trade-offs exist between spatial detail and spectral fidelity.

families.name: Hyperspectral Processing
families.description: Analysis of imagery with numerous narrow spectral bands. Includes dimensionality reduction, spectral unmixing, and material identification. Computational requirements increase with spectral resolution.

families.name: Diffusion-based Methods
families.description: Emerging approaches using diffusion models for image generation and restoration. Applications include denoising, inpainting, and synthetic data generation. Still being evaluated for operational satellite imagery workflows.

tools.name: GDB Empty Layer Cleaner
tools.description: Python utility for identifying and removing empty layers from ESRI File Geodatabase (GDB) files
tools.overview: This tool scans ESRI File Geodatabase (.gdb) directories and identifies layers with zero features. It provides both a graphical interface (Tkinter) and command-line operation for batch processing. The tool helps maintain clean geodatabase structures by removing unused layers that accumulate during data processing workflows.

usage_steps.title: Select or Specify GDB Path
usage_steps.description: Use the GUI file browser or provide the path to your .gdb directory via command line

usage_steps.title: Scan for Empty Layers
usage_steps.description: The tool uses GDAL to iterate through all feature classes and counts features. Empty layers (0 features) are flagged for review

usage_steps.title: Review and Clean
usage_steps.description: View the list of empty layers. Choose to either backup the GDB first (recommended) or perform direct deletion

run_modes.description: Creates a timestamped backup of the entire GDB before deletion. Safe for production environments. Backup location is shown in the UI.
Removes empty layers immediately without backup. Faster but irreversible. Use only on non-critical or already-backed-up data.

features: Handles both feature classes and tables
limitations: Only works with ESRI File Geodatabase format (not Enterprise GDB)
Does not check for relationships or dependencies before deletion
Large GDBs (>10GB) may take several minutes to scan

#!/usr/bin/env python3
# GDB Empty Layer Cleaner
# Lightweight utility for ESRI File Geodatabase maintenance

import os
import shutil
from datetime import datetime
from osgeo import ogr
import tkinter as tk
from tkinter import filedialog, messagebox

def scan_gdb(gdb_path):
    """Scan GDB and return list of empty layers."""
    empty_layers = []
    driver = ogr.GetDriverByName("OpenFileGDB")
    ds = driver.Open(gdb_path, 0)
    
    if ds is None:
        raise ValueError(f"Cannot open GDB: {gdb_path}")
    
    for i in range(ds.GetLayerCount()):
        layer = ds.GetLayerByIndex(i)
        if layer.GetFeatureCount() == 0:
            empty_layers.append(layer.GetName())
    
    ds = None
    return empty_layers

def backup_gdb(gdb_path):
    """Create timestamped backup of GDB."""
    timestamp = datetime.now().strftime("%Y%m%d_%H%M%S")
    backup_path = f"{gdb_path}_backup_{timestamp}"
    shutil.copytree(gdb_path, backup_path)
    return backup_path

def delete_layers(gdb_path, layer_names):
    """Delete specified layers from GDB."""
    driver = ogr.GetDriverByName("OpenFileGDB")
    ds = driver.Open(gdb_path, 1)  # Open with write access
    
    for name in layer_names:
        ds.DeleteLayer(ds.GetLayerIndex(name))
    
    ds = None

def run_gui():
    """Launch Tkinter GUI."""
    root = tk.Tk()
    root.title("GDB Empty Layer Cleaner")
    
    def select_and_scan():
        gdb_path = filedialog.askdirectory(title="Select GDB")
        if not gdb_path:
            return
        
        try:
            empty = scan_gdb(gdb_path)
            if not empty:
                messagebox.showinfo("Result", "No empty layers found.")
                return
            
            msg = f"Found {len(empty)} empty layers:\n" + "\n".join(empty[:10])
            if messagebox.askyesno("Clean?", msg + "\n\nDelete these layers?"):
                backup = backup_gdb(gdb_path)
                delete_layers(gdb_path, empty)
                messagebox.showinfo("Done", f"Cleaned. Backup: {backup}")
        except Exception as e:
            messagebox.showerror("Error", str(e))
    
    tk.Button(root, text="Select GDB and Scan", command=select_and_scan).pack(pady=20)
    root.mainloop()

if __name__ == "__main__":
    run_gui()
